questions.question:
Q1. A 2-year-old child presents for evaluation with an abnormal head shape and a
distinctive hand deformity as shown in the image. The child's head exhibits early
closure of cranial sutures, leading to an unusually shaped skull. Based on these clinical
features, which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?

Q2. Arrange the following in the correct sequence of eruption for primary and
permanent teeth. Primary lateral incisors Primary central incisors Permanent first
premolar Primary second molar Permanent first molar Primary canine
Q3. At what age does the anterior fontanelle typically close in infants?

Q4. Match the following graphical representations with their respective cause of short
stature. i) Familial short stature ii) Constitutional delay iii) Pre-natal onset pathologic
short stature

Q5. Match the following. A. 1. Scaphocephaly B. 2. Plagiocephaly C. 3. Brachycephaly
D. 4. Trigonocephaly

Q6. A one-year-old child presents with macrocephaly, developmental delay, a
significant reduction in motor skills, poor muscle tone, and a low IQ. At birth the child
was normal. Fundoscopy reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Q7. Which of the following conditions is not a cause of acquired microcephaly?

Q8. A newborn is evaluated and has a head circumference < -2 SD of the mean for age
and sex. The baby’s head circumference is consistently below this threshold on
repeated measurements, No additional findings of developmental delay or
neurological impairment. Which of the following is the most appropriate condition for
this baby?

options.a: Microcephaly is probably due to Seckel syndrome.
options.b: Microcephaly is probably due to the Zika virus in the antenatal period.

questions.question:
Q9. A 4-year-old child presents with developmental delays and a recent diagnosis of
homocystinuria. Physical examination reveals tall stature, dislocated lens, and a
history of recurrent thrombotic events. Genetic testing and biochemical analysis
confirm the diagnosis. Which amino acid is most closely linked to the metabolic
pathway involved in the development of homocystinuria?

Q10. Which of the following statements regarding the causes and characteristics of tall
stature in children are correct? Tall stature is defined as a height >2SD above the
mean for age and gender. Constitutional acceleration of growth (CAG) is
characterized by tall stature, normal growth velocity, and advanced bone age, and
results in a final height within the mid-parental range. Tall stature is defined as a
height >3SD above the mean for age and gender. Obesity-related tall stature is
associated with advanced bone age and early onset of puberty, which may limit the
increase in final height. Klinefelter syndrome presents with disproportionately tall
stature, small testes, and behavioral issues. Marfan syndrome, caused by mutations in
the FBN1 gene, features tall stature, lens dislocation, and aortic root dilation.

Q11. A 6-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a history of frequent bone fractures
occurring with minimal trauma. Physical examination reveals a blue sclera, hearing,
and dental abnormalities. Which of the following statements best explains the
underlying pathophysiology of the patient's condition?

options.a: Mutation affects collagen type II, leading to bone fractures.
options.b: Mutation affects collagen type III, resulting in blue sclera.
options.c: Mutation affects collagen type I, affecting bones and contributing to their fragility.
options.d: Mutation affects collagen type IV, resulting in dental abnormalities.

questions.question:
Q12. A 7-year-old boy presents with short stature and disproportionate body
proportions. His parents are concerned about his height, which falls well below the
3rd percentile for his age. The child has a normal-sized trunk but exhibits a
disproportionately large head and short limbs. X-ray findings show shortening of the
long bones and normal bone mineralization. Genetic testing reveals a specific FGFR3
mutation. What is the most likely diagnosis for this child's short stature?

Q13. A 10-year-old boy presents with short stature and delayed bone age. His growth
velocity has been consistently below the 3rd percentile. After thorough evaluation,
growth hormone deficiency (GHD) is diagnosed. What is the expected relationship
between the Upper and Lower segments of his body?

Q14. What will the expected adult height of a male child be if the adult height of the
mother is 168 cm and the adult height of the father is 182 cm?

Q15. A concerned mother brings her 2-year-old child, worried about the child's short
stature. On examination, it is found that the child’s bone age matches the
chronological age but the height falls more than 2 standard deviations below the
average for the child's age. The child has no other developmental anomalies, and both
parents are of short stature. What is the most likely cause of the short stature in this
child?

Q16. Which of the following best defines the time limit used to describe the term
"embryo" in human development?

Q17. Which of the following conditions are most likely to be associated with delayed
dentition? Rickets Cleidocranial dysostosis Pierre Robin sequence Down syndrome

Q18. A 2-month-old infant is being evaluated for growth parameters. The pediatrician
needs to measure the chest circumference accurately. What is the most appropriate
position for this measurement?

options.a: At the end of the expiration
options.c: At the end of deep inspiration
options.d: At the level of nipples, irrespective of the inspiratory or expiratory phase

questions.question:
Q19. If the head circumference of a newborn is 35 cm, what would be the expected
measurement at 1 year of age?

Q20. A 6-year-old child presents after a road traffic accident, and accurate height
measurement using a stadiometer is not possible. Which of the following methods is
most appropriate for estimating the child’s height?

options.b: Estimating height based on parental height

questions.question:
Q21. At what age is a child's height typically around half of their predicted adult
height?

Q22. A 6-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic for a routine check-up. The
pediatrician wants to estimate her weight. What will be the estimated weight of this
6-year-old girl?

Q23. In the pediatric population, which aspect of growth is most closely correlated
with the maturation of the gonads?

Q24. A 12-year-old child’s growth chart shows a distinctive pattern in the graph
depicting their growth over time as shown in the image below. In this clinical scenario,
what does the graph primarily indicate about the child’s growth patterns?

Q25. A 4-year-old child presents for a routine checkup. The pediatrician reviews the
child’s health and plots the following parameters on the growth chart. Which of the
following parameters is not typically represented on the WHO growth chart?

Q26. A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. The pediatrician
uses the Growth Charts to assess growth patterns. Which of the following charts is
used in this patient?

options.b: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Growth Charts
options.c: National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) Growth Charts

questions.question:
Q27. Arrange the following pubertal changes in females in the correct sequence from
the first to the last: Pubarche Thelarche Growth Spurt Menarche

Q28. A 7-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic for a routine check-up.
Parents are concerned about her weight gain and overall growth. The pediatrician
decides to assess nutritional status and body fat distribution by assessing skin fold
thickness to determine if any concerns need to be addressed. Which of the following
instruments is best used?

Q29. Which of the following is not assessed by measuring MUAC (Middle upper arm
circumference?

Q1. While evaluating a 3-year-old with short stature, height is measured at 90cm and
the lower segment is 45 cm. What is the likely diagnosis?
Q2. At which of the following ages does maximum brain growth occur?

Q3. A 10 year old child presented to the clinic with complaints of recurrent infection.
Physical examination shows low height for age and Z line score is <-2SD. The parents
also have a history of incorrect feeding method. What is the appropriate term for the
above mentioned condition?

Q4. Which of the following is the best sign to indicate adequate growth in an infant
with a birth weight of 2.8 kg?

options.a: Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year
options.b: Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year
options.c: Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age
options.d: Weight under the 75th percentile and height under the 25th percentile

questions.question:
Q5. A 6-year-old child is brought for evaluation of short stature. His height is
comparable with his parent’s height and his bone age corresponds to his chronological
age. What is the diagnosis?
Q6. Gonadal growth corresponds with _____.

Q7. Which alternative method can be used for the procedure shown in the image
below?
Q8. Which is the first primary tooth to erupt?

Q9. A child is brought to the paediatrician with short stature. On evaluation, growth
hormone levels are found to be high and insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels are
low. Which among the following could be the abnormality here?

Q10. A 16-month-old boy weighs 8 kg. A WHO growth chart (weight-for-age) is
provided below. What is the most appropriate advice for this child?

options.c: Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation centre
options.d: Moderate malnutrition - teach the mother how to feed

questions.question:
Q11. A 3-year-old child is brought to the OPD for a regular check-up. His growth
chart shows a BMI between the 85th and 95th percentile . Which of the following
categories would you place him in?

Q12. A mother expresses concern about her child's unwillingness to eat properly . Her
15-month-old son's length falls 2 standard deviations below the median for his age .
What is the most probable medical condition ?
Q13. How many primary teeth does a 3-year-old child have?

Q14. Where would you place the pulse oximeter to measure preductal oxygen
saturation in an infant born 3 minutes ago?
Q1. Copies cross, tells stories, and goes to the toilet alone. What is the age of the child?

Q2. According to the expanded New Ballard score, which of the options listed below is
considered a part of the neuromuscular criteria for assessing maturity?
Q3. When compared to WHO-ORS, low osmolarity ORS has which of the following?
Q4. The earliest indication of sexual maturation in females:

Social smile b 6-7 months 3 Pincer grasp c 12-15 months 4 Walks 1-2 steps d 9-12
months
Q6. In an infant, which of the following milestones is achieved the earliest?
Q7. Handedness is seen at the age of _____
Q8. What is the underlying defect in the congenital malformation shown below?

Q9. How do you calculate the mid-parental height for a male child with a father who is
183 cm tall and a mother who is 175 cm tall?

Q10. What is the likely age of a child who can ride a tricycle, walk up stairs with
alternate steps, but cannot hop?
Q11. At what age does the transfer of one object to another hand happen?

Q12. What is the rate of increase in head circumference in infants less than 3 months
of age?
Q13. At what age does stranger anxiety appear?

Q14. During a routine pediatric check-up, a mother brings her 5 month old baby to
the clinic. The pediatrician observes that the baby actively looks at his mother’s face
and seems to respond with interest as she talks to him, showing recognition and
engagement. When is this milestone normally achieved?

Q15. What is the rate of increase in head circumference in infants at the first 3 months
of age?

Q16. While you are evaluating a baby , you show him a bright pink teddy bear that he
reaches out to with both hands. What is the earliest age by which this milestone is
typically achieved?

Q17. If a 3-year-old child does not attain one of the following milestones, it is
considered developmental delay . Which milestone is being referred to here?

Q1. What could be the possible diagnosis for a 2-year-old child who had a parietal
bone fracture from a fall one year ago and is now experiencing a painful parietal
swelling that is increasing in size?
Q1. At what age does a child reach half of their adult height?
Q2. A child with an IQ of 55 comes under:

Q3. Following the delivery of a baby born to a mother with diabetes, the infant's blood
glucose level was measured to be 60 mg/dl. What additional examination would you
perform?

Q4. What is the recommended treatment for a 7-year-old child presenting with
bedwetting complaints?
Q5. Intellectual disability is seen in:
Q6. Craniopagus is defined as the fusion of:

Q1. A full-term neonate born to a healthy mother presents on the third day of life with
a birth weight of 2.9 kg, length of 50 cm, head circumference of 35 cm, heart rate of
130 bpm, respiratory rate of 50 breaths/min, and peripheral cyanosis noted on the
extremities. The baby is passing urine but has not passed any stools till now. Which of
the following findings in this neonate would be most concerning?

options.a: Peripheral cyanosis (acrocyanosis) noted on the extremities
options.b: Passage of the first stool after 48 hours of birth

questions.question:
Q2. A 3-month-old infant is brought for a checkup. The pediatrician notices that when
the baby's head is rotated to one side, the arm on the same side extends, and the arm
on the opposite side flexes. Which of the following best explains these observations?

Q3. A newborn is delivered at 36 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 1,200
grams. How should this newborn be classified based on gestational age and birth
weight?

options.b: Term and Very Low Birth Weight (VLBW)
options.c: Pre-term and Very Low Birth Weight (VLBW)

questions.question:
Q4. A 38-week gestational-age infant is delivered with a birth weight of 3,200 grams.
The neonatal team assesses the infant's weight percentile and notes that it falls
between the 10th and 90th percentile for their gestational age. How should this
newborn be classified according to gestational age and birth weight?

Q5. A 43-week-old postterm neonate is delivered vaginally. Which of the following is
not a characteristic appearance of a post-term neonate?

options.c: Visible creases on palms and soles

questions.question:
Q6. A newborn is admitted to the NICU with signs of hypoglycemia and respiratory
distress. The mother had multiple gestation and gestational diabetes during her
pregnancy. Which of the following is not a pregnancy-related complication that
contributes to the high-risk status of this infant?

Q7. A 2-month-old infant is brought to the clinic for a developmental check-up. Which
reflex should the clinician expect to see at this stage of development?

Q8. A 1-day-old newborn shows no startle response to sudden movement or sound.
The pediatrician notes an absent Moro reflex, with no asymmetry. The baby is alert
but cries weakly. What is the most likely cause?

Q9. Match the following images with their distinguishing features 1) a) Benign
capillary malformation 2) b) Contains eosinophils 3) c) Contains melanocytes 4) d)
Contains keratin

Q10. Which of the following conditions in newborns typically resolves on its own
without treatment?

Q11. Which of the following statements are true regarding the neonatal conditions
described? Mastitis neonatorum typically presents with bilateral breast swelling
Vaginal bleeding in neonates usually resolves within 10 days. Hymenal tags are usually
symptomatic and often require medical treatment. Term neonates can lose up to 10%
of their birth weight in the first week of life. Physiologic phimosis usually resolves by
age 3-5 and is generally asymptomatic. Preterm infants regain their birth weight
within 7-10 days.

Q12. A 12-hour-old infant on routine examination presents with a well-defined, firm
mass on the head. The mass is located over the parietal bones and does not cross the
suture lines. The parents mention that the mass became noticeable shortly after birth
and has been increasing in size for the past few hours. Which of the following is the
most likely diagnosis?

Q1. During neonatal resuscitation, If the HR is less than 100/min or apnea or gasping
is present what measures would you take?

options.a: Start PPV by self-inflating the Bag and Mask
options.c: Reassess after 30 seconds, if the HR is not less than 100/min then the baby gets post-resuscitation

questions.question:
Q2. A 24-year-old primigravida came for a routine antenatal check at 32 weeks
gestation. As the medical officer, which of the following is your responsibility during
the antenatal period? A. Antenatal counseling for the mother B. Team briefing and
individual responsibility allocation C. Equipment check and preparation D. Proper
history taking i.e. prior history of preterm delivery or abortions

Q3. A 27-year-old mother gave birth to a term male baby through normal vaginal
delivery with a birth weight of 3 kg who did not cry immediately after birth. How will
you resuscitate the baby?

options.b: Position the baby properly to ensure an open airway; the neck should be kept slightly extended and
options.c: Stimulate the baby i.e. providing physical stimulation by rubbing the back of the baby or flicking the

questions.question:
Q4. During neonatal resuscitation, If the HR is less than 100/min despite PPV, the
following steps are followed except:

options.a: Ensure, whether the positive pressure ventilation is given properly or not
options.d: If needed endotracheal intubation should be done.

questions.question:
Q5. After delivery and resuscitation, a neonate was found to have HR <60 even after
effective positive pressure ventilation and no respiratory efforts. What is the line of
action?

Q6. What is the recommended dose of adrenaline for neonatal resuscitation in a
preterm baby at NICU with HR persistently below 60/min?

Q7. Which among the given statements is wrong regarding resuscitation of newborn?
a) The recommended pressure of suction is 80 mmHg b) Correct order of suction:
mouth followed by nose. c) The recommended pressure should never exceed >80
mmHg d) Correct order of suction: nose followed by mouth
Q8. Which of the following is the wrong statement about PPV?

options.a: The reservoir bag and oxygen tubing may or may not be attached to the self-inflating bag
options.b: The function of the reservoir is to increase FiO2 delivered to the baby
options.c: The single most important step in neonatal resuscitation is effective positive pressure ventilation.
options.d: The rate of PPV should be 30-40/min

questions.question:
Q9. A 6-hour-old term baby shifted to emergency brought with severe respiratory
distress. Chest X-ray is given below. Which of the initial clinical interventions should
not be done on this patient?

options.a: Intubation and insertion of nasogastric tube
options.d: Put the baby in a radiant warmer.

questions.question:
Q10. All of the following are the key corrective actions to optimize ventilation during
neonatal resuscitation except:

options.a: Ensure the mask is of appropriate size
options.b: The seal between mask and face should be tight
options.c: The mask should cover the mouth only
options.d: The head of the baby should be slightly extended and the mouth of the baby is kept slightly open

questions.question:
Q11. What is the most reliable method to confirm proper placement of an
endotracheal tube immediately after intubation?

options.c: Visualization of the tube passing through the vocal cords

questions.question:
Q12. As a part of neonatal resuscitation, you start chest compressions. For maximum
effectiveness, what should be the depth of your compressions?

options.a: I of AP diameter of chest
options.b: ½ of AP diameter of chest
options.c: I of AP diameter of chest
options.d: ¼ of AP diameter of chest

questions.question:
Q13. Which of the following is one of the primary benefits of delayed umbilical cord
clamping in newborns?

options.a: It reduces the risk of maternal postpartum hemorrhage
options.b: It decreases the likelihood of neonatal jaundice
options.c: It prevents the need for neonatal resuscitation
options.d: It improves the newborn’s iron stores and reduces the risk of anemia

questions.question:
Q14. Under which of the following conditions will neonatal resuscitation not be
performed?

Q1. A neonate born after an emergency c-section due to non-reassuring fetal heart
tones was noted to have poor muscle tone, a heart rate of 70 bpm, and intermittent
gasping respirations. Despite initial tactile stimulation, the infant becomes flaccid and
apneic. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology?

options.a: Prolonged hypoxia causes progressive neuromuscular depression
options.c: Acute hypoxia leads to metabolic alkalosis
options.d: Persistent hypocapnia causes central respiratory depression

questions.question:
Q2. A neonate delivered via emergency cesarean section presents with an Apgar score
of 2 at 1 minute. Which of the following criteria is most indicative of severe birth
asphyxia?

options.a: Persistent metabolic alkalosis with a high base deficit
options.b: Apgar score of 5 at 5 minutes and normal blood pH
options.c: Blood pH <7.0 on umbilical arterial blood gas with a high base deficit
options.d: Presence of mild hypotonia and a base deficit of 10 mmol/L

questions.question:
Q3. A term newborn is diagnosed with moderate Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy
(HIE) after experiencing birth asphyxia. The infant is currently receiving supportive
care. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of
this infant?

Q4. A 24-hour-old infant shows lethargy, hypotonia, intermittent seizures, and weak
sucking reflex following a complicated delivery. According to the Sarnat classification,
which stage of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) does this infant most likely
have?

Q5. A multigravida G2P1L1 delivers a baby at 37 weeks of gestation by cesarean
section. On assessment, the baby was completely cyanosed having slow and irregular
breathing with a heart rate of 76 bpm, and he was showing slight flexion on
stimulation along with a slight frown when stimulated by an orogastric tube. Calculate
the APGAR score for the baby.

Q6. A primigravida delivered a baby at 34 weeks of gestation. The baby was cyanosed
and grunting, with a respiratory rate of 72 bpm. Which of the following scores can be
used to assess this condition?

Q7. A primigravida with a complicated pregnancy underwent a cesarean section at 32
weeks of gestation. Soon after birth, the baby developed grunting, cyanosis, and a
significantly elevated respiratory rate. A chest X-ray was performed immediately.
Which of the following findings would not be seen on the given radiograph?

Q8. In the lab, amniotic fluid is mixed with 95% ethyl alcohol and then left after
shaking it vigorously. After 15 minutes, a complete rim of bubbles is seen. Which of
the following tests is described here ?

Q9. Which of the following interventions is NOT typically used in the initial
management of neonatal Respiratory Distress Syndrome?

Q10. At what gestational age range is the administration of antenatal corticosteroids
typically recommended to reduce the risk of Respiratory Distress Syndrome(RDS) in
preterm infants?

Q11. A 39-week pregnant woman in active labour experiences spontaneous rupture of
membranes, revealing thick, green amniotic fluid. The fetal heart rate tracing shows
late decelerations. After delivery, the newborn has poor respiratory effort, cyanosis,
and visible meconium staining on the skin. Which of the following is the most
appropriate immediate management for this newborn?

options.b: Stimulation and provision of positive pressure ventilation

questions.question:
Q12. Which of the following is NOT typically associated with Transient Tachypnea of
the Newborn (TTN)?

options.a: More common in infants delivered by cesarean section
options.c: Persistent hypoxemia requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation
options.d: Delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid

questions.question:
Q13. A 27-week gestational-age preterm infant in the NICU experiences persistent
apnea lasting over 20 seconds despite gentle tactile stimulation and supplemental
oxygen. Nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP) has been used but has not
resolved the episodes. What is the most appropriate next step?

options.a: Continue nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP)

questions.question:
Q14. A day-old preterm infant is admitted with severe respiratory distress. Physical
examination shows a scaphoid abdomen and a chest X-ray image is given below.
Despite intensive care, the infant's condition deteriorates. Which of the following
statements about the suspected condition is correct?

options.a: Bochdalek typically occurs on the right side.
options.c: Morgagni is associated with poor prognosis.

questions.question:
Q15. A 2-day-old newborn diagnosed with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH)
presents with severe respiratory distress and is scheduled for urgent surgical
intervention. Which of the following management strategies is not recommended in
this setting?

options.d: Nasogastric tube to decompress the stomach

questions.question:
Q16. A 3-day-old newborn with congenital diaphragmatic hernia is in NICU showing
signs of severe respiratory distress. Despite intensive management, the infant's
condition deteriorates and leads to death. What is the most common cause of death in
CDH?

Q1. A 2700-g male infant, born at 36 weeks gestation, presents at 6 hours of age with
grunting, nasal flaring, and intercostal retractions. He is also experiencing poor
feeding. His temperature is 35.8°C, and blood pressure is 42 mm Hg systolic. A CBC
shows a WBC count of 2500 cells/mm3 with 80% bands. What is the most likely
diagnosis?

Q2. A 32-week pregnant woman presents due to concerns about her baby's growth.
Her pregnancy has been complicated by chronic hypertension. The ultrasound reveals
that the fetal head size is within the normal range, but the body weight and length are
significantly below the 10th percentile. What is the most likely etiology of the fetal
growth restriction in this case?
Q3. Which of the following best describes morphological IUGR?

options.a: Birth weight below the 10th percentile with malnutrition.
options.b: Birth weight between the 10th and 25th percentiles with malnutrition.
options.c: Birth weight above the 25th percentile with malnutrition.
options.d: Birth weight at the 50th percentile with no malnutrition

questions.question:
Q4. A 30-year-old pregnant woman is in her second trimester with a history of mild
hypertension. Her obstetrician is concerned about the risk of IUGR due to her history
. Which of the following strategies should be recommended to prevent IUGR?

Q5. A 14-day-old preterm infant (35 weeks gestation) presents with worsening
respiratory distress, irritability, and poor feeding. The mother reports poor cord care
and the infant is febrile (38°C). Based on the clinical presentation and age, what is the
most likely type and timing of sepsis in this infant?

options.a: Early-onset sepsis occurring up to 72 hours after birth
options.b: Early-onset sepsis occurring after 72 hours but before 7 days of life
options.c: Late-onset sepsis occurring beyond 7 days of life
options.d: Very late-onset sepsis occurring more than 10 days after birth

questions.question:
Q6. A 2-day-old, term neonate presents with lethargy, poor feeding, and mild
hypothermia. You suspect neonatal sepsis and order a sepsis screen as part of the
diagnostic workup.Which of the following findings would be included in the sepsis
screen for this neonate?

options.d: Decreased absolute neutrophil count as per Mouzinho’s chart.

questions.question:
Q7. A 3-day-old neonate presents with fever, irritability, and poor feeding. The sepsis
screen is equivocal, but a lumbar puncture confirms the diagnosis of bacterial
meningitis. Blood culture is pending, but the clinical team decides to initiate treatment
immediately. Which of the following is the most appropriate antibiotic regimen and
duration of therapy for this neonate?

options.a: Oral Cefotaxime and Gentamicin for 21 days
options.b: IV Cefotaxime and Gentamicin for 14 days
options.c: IV Ampicillin and Gentamicin for 21 days
options.d: IV Cefotaxime and Gentamicin for 21 days

questions.question:
Q8. During a routine examination of a newborn weighing 2.5 kg, 15 minutes after
birth, you would classify the neonate as having moderate hypothermia if the body
temperature is:

Q9. Which of the following statements is incorrect about Kangaroo Mother Care
(KMC)? I. KMC is only recommended for preterm infants weighing less than 1500
grams. II. KMC must be performed continuously for at least 24 hours a day to be
effective. III. KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500 g and a gestational age
of 37 weeks. IV. KMC is as good as incubator care in terms of safety and thermal care.

Q10. A full-term neonate is born in a resource-limited rural health center. The
delivery room temperature is 20°C. Which of the following steps is not part of the
warm chain that should be immediately implemented to prevent neonatal
hypothermia?

options.a: Drying the baby immediately after birth.
options.b: Skin-to-skin contact between the mother and baby.
options.c: Covering the baby’s head with a warm cap.
options.d: Bathing the baby in warm water

questions.question:
Q11. A 3-day-old preterm neonate is brought to the NICU with an axillary
temperature of 31.5°C after being found hypothermic in the maternity ward. The
baby is placed under a radiant warmer, and rewarming measures are initiated. After
1 hour, the baby's temperature is rechecked. Which of the following indicates that the
rewarming process is proceeding at an appropriate rate for neonatal hypothermia?

options.a: The baby's temperature rises to 34°C within the first hour.
options.b: The baby's temperature rises to 36.5°C within 2 hours.
options.c: The baby's temperature rises by 0.5°C within the first hour.
options.d: The baby's temperature rises by 0.2°C within the first hour.

questions.question:
Q12. A 1-day-old term neonate born to a mother with gestational diabetes is found to
have a blood glucose level of 30 mg/dL during routine screening. The baby is
asymptomatic and has been breastfeeding moderately well. What is the most
appropriate next step in the management of this neonate?

options.b: Administer a bolus of 2 mL/kg of 10% dextrose and then start glucose infusion.
options.c: Provide a trial of oral feeds and recheck blood glucose in 30-45 minutes.
options.d: Repeat the blood glucose test after 1 hour without feeding and monitor.

questions.question:
Q13. You are examining an LGA neonate who presents with the physical finding
shown in the image below. Given this finding, you suspect the neonate might have an
associated congenital heart anomaly. What is the most common congenital heart
anomaly you would suspect in this case?

Q1. A 29-year-old Rh-negative woman, 30 weeks pregnant, presents for a routine
follow-up. She has a history of a previous pregnancy complicated by Rh
incompatibility but has been receiving appropriate prenatal care. Recent laboratory
tests reveal a positive indirect Coombs test with elevated anti-Rh antibodies. The fetal
ultrasound shows normal growth and no significant abnormalities. What is the most
likely diagnosis for the fetus?

options.d: Severe Hemolytic Disease of Newborn with Normal Growth

questions.question: Q2. Which of the following is true about the scoring tool?

options.a: Used solely to assess the neuromuscular maturity
options.b: Used to assess gestational age based on Physical and Neuromuscular maturity
options.c: Used only to ascess physical maturity
options.d: Used exclusively to determine the baby's weight

questions.question:
Q3. Refer to the image provided. Which of the following statements is correct
regarding the features shown in the image?

options.a: The system provides an open care environment
options.b: The system does not include an option for humidification.

Q3. A 10-year-old child has been diagnosed with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity
Disorder (ADHD). The primary approach for managing ADHD involves several
strategies. Which of the following treatment options is the most appropriate first-line
approach for managing ADHD in children?

options.a: Immediate initiation of treatment with methylphenidate.
options.b: Intensive cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) as the sole treatment option.
options.c: Implementation of behavioral interventions and psychotherapy tailored to the individual, with
options.d: Referral to a specialist for neurological evaluation before starting behavorial therapy.

questions.question:
Q4. A 7-year-old is brought to the clinic with complaints of low academic
performance. He has difficulty listening in class, often makes careless mistakes,
frequently interrupts others, is restless and is often fidgeting during lessons. He has
had symptoms for the past year.Based on the above scenario which diagnosis is most
likely ?
Q5. Which of the following statements is true regarding PICA in children?

options.a: PICA is observed only in children who have experienced severe emotional trauma or neglect.
options.b: PICA is characterized by the persistent ingestion of non-nutritive substances for at least 1 month..
options.c: Typically occurs in children between 5-10 years.
options.d: Low socioeconomic status is not a risk factor.

questions.question:
Q6. A 2-year-old boy has had several episodes- of turning pale or bluish and losing
consciousness for a brief period. These episodes occur when he is upset or frustrated,
no other significant symptoms and development is normal. During these events, he is
unresponsive for about 30 seconds and then recovers spontaneously. What is the most
appropriate initial management?

options.a: ECG to rule out underlying cardiac issues and reassure about the disease.
options.b: Reassure and educate about the disease.
options.c: Administration of oral iron supplements to address possible iron deficiency anemia.
options.d: Initiation of anticonvulsant medication to prevent further episodes.

questions.question:
Q7. A 4-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her parents reporting that she initially
met her developmental milestones but has recently begun to lose previously acquired
skills. They also mention that she has started to exhibit repetitive hand movements
and difficulty with motor control. On examination, you observe that she has a
characteristic hand-wringing movement and a loss of purposeful hand movements.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this child?

developmental red flag?

developmental delays. The child was born at term with a low birth weight. Which of
the following conditions is most likely to be the underlying cause?

pronouns.What is the child's Developmental Quotient (DQ) of the child in the
language domain?

Q11. Which among the following developmental milestones is not developed by the age
of 9 months?

blanket. Instead of forgetting about it, Emma lifts the blanket to find the bunny. What

months d. 1-2 words with meaning

developmental milestone she achieved at 15 months?

development of a child?

options.a: Sequence of attainment of milestone is same in all children
options.b: Disorganized mass activity is replaced by specific actions
options.c: Primitive reflexes have to be lost before relevant milestone are attained
options.d: The process of development progresses from toe to head.

questions.question:
Q19. During a routine pediatric check-up, a mother brings her 5 month old baby to
the clinic. The pediatrician observes that the baby actively looks at his mother’s face
and seems to respond with interest as she talks to him, showing recognition and
engagement. When is this milestone normally achieved?

Q20. During a developmental check-up, a pediatrician observes a group of toddlers at
a local playgroup. The children are engaged in playing with toys independently but
are situated close to one another. Each child seems focused on their own activity,
occasionally glancing at the others but not interacting directly.At what age is this type
of play most commonly observed?

Q1. A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a history of
profuse watery diarrhea and multiple episodes of vomiting for the past 3 days. On
examination, he appears lethargic, has poor oral acceptance, and has dry mucous
membranes. Laboratory tests reveal serum potassium of 2.8 mEq/L. Which of the

blood pressure monitoring during major surgery, the anesthesiologist compresses both
the radial and ulnar arteries, asks the child to make a fist, then releases the ulnar
artery while keeping the radial artery compressed. What is the primary purpose of
this maneuver?

options.a: To assess the elasticity of the arterial walls
options.b: To evaluate collateral circulation in the hand
options.c: To determine the size of the radial artery

questions.question:

appropriate initial management?

options.a: Administer 20 mL/kg of normal saline over 1 hour
options.c: Give 20 mL/kg of normal saline as a rapid bolus

questions.question:

unit. What is the recommended fluid requirement for this infant on day 2 of life?

options.d: After puberty, males have slightly more total body water than females.

questions.question:
Q12. A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of
headache, nausea, and confusion. He was recently treated for bacterial meningitis.

show: Serum sodium: 128 mEq/L Serum osmolality: 265 mOsm/kg Urine sodium: 55

the Schwartz and Bartter Clinical Criterion, which of the following is NOT a
diagnostic criterion for Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion
(SIADH)?

lethargy. His medical history includes cirrhosis. Physical examination reveals
peripheral edema and ascites. Laboratory tests show: Serum sodium: 128 mEq/L
Serum creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL Total protein: 5.5 g/dL (low) Albumin: 2.8 g/dL (low)
Which of the following best describes the type of this patient's condition?

Q14. Which of the following is not likely the cause of hypernatremia in the pediatric
age group?

vomiting for the past 2 days. He appears dehydrated and lethargic. Laboratory studies

Urinary Chloride: 10 mEq/L Which of the following is the MOST appropriate initial
treatment for this patient's acid-base disorder?

Q16. A 5-year-old patient presents with resistant hypertension that has not improved
despite various antihypertensive treatments. Laboratory tests reveal normal levels of

most likely to be the underlying cause of the patient’s hypertension?

options.a: An activating mutation of sodium channels in the distal nephron
options.c: A loss-of-function mutation in the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system
options.d: An activating mutation of sodium channels in the loop

questions.question:

Alkalosis in children?

options.a: It responds to fluid replacement with normal saline

questions.question:

metabolic acidosis

options.a: Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

mother says he is irritable and drinks water hastily when given. On examination, eyes

options.a: Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher center

options.d: Consider severe dehydration, start intravenous (IV) fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher centre

options.d: Kearns-Sayre syndrome and Pearson syndrome do not follow this type of inheritance.

questions.question: Q3. Which of the following statements about the BCG vaccine is false?

options.a: Provides ~40% protection against primary TB and up to 100% against miliary TB.

options.c: Can be given until age 5 according to IAP 2021 guidelines.

questions.question:
Q4. A nurse at a Primary Health Center (PHC) is preparing vaccines for an outreach
program. She needs to prioritize handling the most heat-sensitive vaccines to prevent
them from losing potency. Which of the following vaccines is the most sensitive to
heat?

Q5. A nurse is inspecting vaccines in a clinic before administering them to children.
She notices that one of the vials of hepatitis B vaccine appears suspicious. To ensure
the vaccine's integrity, she performs a shake test. After vigorous shaking, she observes
that the vaccine in the vial has a sediment that settles at the bottom, unlike another
vial she shakes which remains uniformly cloudy. Based on the results of the shake test,
which of the following actions should the nurse take?

options.a: Administer the vaccine with the sediment as it is still safe to use.
options.b: Administer the uniformly cloudy vaccine as it is not damaged by freezing.
options.c: Discard both vials as they show signs of potential damage.
options.d: Use the vial with the sediment as a control and proceed with the uniformly cloudy vaccine.

questions.question: Q6. Which of the following statements about the HPV vaccines is false?

options.d: Catch-up vaccination for the Gardasil 4 HPV vaccine is available for individuals up to 45 years of

options.a: Administer three additional PCV13 doses: two 4 weeks apart, the third 8 weeks later.
options.b: Give one dose of PPSV23 now, no more PCV13 is needed.
options.c: Administer one additional dose of PCV13 at 24-59 months.
options.d: No further PCV13 doses are needed since the child is over 2 years old.

options.c: The Typhoid Vi capsular polysaccharide vaccine is recommended every 5 years.
options.d: The Rotavirus vaccine vial can be used for up to 4 hours after opening.

options.b: Give both the first Hepatitis A dose and an additional Hepatitis B dose.

options.d: Administer the first dose of the Measles vaccine now and schedule the next dose at 4-6 years.

options.c: Administer DPT and monitor for severe side effects like encephalopathy.
options.d: No further vaccines are needed after completing the Pentavalent series.

questions.question:
Q12. In response to the emergence of circulating vaccine-derived polioviruses
(cVDPVs), which of the following strategies has been implemented globally to address
this issue?

options.a: Exclusively using trivalent oral polio vaccine (OPV) to enhance herd immunity.
options.b: Transitioning from trivalent OPV to bivalent OPV (bOPV) and introducing inactivated polio vaccine
options.c: Replacing all OPV doses with IPV doses in the primary immunization schedule.
options.d: Discontinuing the use of any polio vaccines and relying on natural immunity.

questions.question:
Q13. A 10-week-old infant is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. The mother
reports that the baby received the first dose of Hepatitis B at birth but missed the
scheduled vaccinations at 6 weeks. Which of the following should be administered to
the infant at this visit to catch up with the National Immunisation Schedule?

Q14. A preterm infant born at 28 weeks of gestation weighs 1.8 kg at birth. The
infant's mother is HBsAg-positive. Which of the following is the correct management
for hepatitis B vaccination in this infant?

options.a: Administer the hepatitis B birth dose within the first 24 hours of life.
options.b: Defer the hepatitis B birth dose until the infant reaches 1 month of age.
options.c: Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) and hepatitis B vaccine within 12 hours of birth.
options.d: Administer hepatitis B vaccine only after discharge from the hospital.

questions.question:
Q15. According to the World Health Organization (WHO) classification, which of the
following is classified as a severe vaccine reaction?

options.a: Pain, swelling, or redness at the injection site
options.c: Severe allergic reaction requiring emergency treatment

questions.question:
Q16. Which of the following is an example of a vaccine-induced adverse event
following immunization?

options.b: Toxic shock syndrome due to a contaminated vaccine

questions.question:
Q17. Which of the following vaccines is not administered via intramuscular (IM)
injection according to the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) of India?

Q18. A 14 y/o girl who missed her HPV vaccination series as a pre-teen is now seeking
to catch up. What is the most appropriate action according to the vaccination
guidelines?

options.a: Start the full HPV vaccine series immediately.
options.b: Administer a single dose of HPV vaccine.
options.c: Delay vaccination until she is 18 years old.
options.d: Perform serologic testing before initiating the HPV vaccine series.

questions.question:
Q19. Which of the following vaccines should be discarded at the end of an
immunization session if partially used?

Q20. Which of the following correctly describes the purpose of the shake test in
vaccine management?

options.a: To check if the vaccine has been exposed to excessive heat
options.b: To determine if the vaccine has been frozen and potentially damaged
options.c: To verify the expiration date of the vaccine
options.d: To assess the potency of the vaccine by checking its colour

questions.question:
Q21. A 7 y/o foster child presents to the clinic with an undocumented immunization
history. The caretakers are unsure if the child received any vaccines. What is the most
appropriate next step in managing this child?

options.a: Delay vaccination until the immunization history is confirmed.
options.c: Vaccine-preventable diseases are no longer a concern.
options.d: Administer only the first dose of each vaccine and wait for serologic confirmation.

questions.question:
Q22. A 6-month-old infant arrives at the clinic for their scheduled vaccinations. The
mother mentions that the baby has a mild cough and runny nose but no fever. She is
also concerned because the baby vomited 15 minutes after receiving the last dose of
OPV during the previous visit. Which of the following is the most appropriate action
for the healthcare provider to take today?

options.a: Administer all scheduled vaccines, including a repeat dose of OPV.
options.b: Withhold all vaccines and reschedule for when the child is symptom-free.
options.c: Restart the entire vaccination series from the beginning.
options.d: Administer all scheduled vaccines except OPV due to the previous vomiting episode.

questions.question:
Q23. A 1 y/o child is assessed for vaccination status. The records show the child has
received all vaccines recommended for the first year. Which of the following vaccines
has the child not received as part of being fully immunized according to the National
Immunisation Schedule?

Q1. A 5-year-old unimmunized child presents to the OPD with a fully immunized
2-year-old sibling. Upon inspection, a white membranous layer is observed in the
throat of the 5-year-old. What is the next step in management for the contact?

Q2. In which of the following conditions is live vaccination not contraindicated?
DiGeorge syndrome Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome Ataxia telangiectasia Complement
deficiency

Q3. What should be the course of action for the newborn if the mother, who is a
first-time pregnant woman, arrives at the hospital at 37 weeks of pregnancy with no
prior antenatal check-ups and is currently in labor, while also testing positive for
Hepatitis B?

options.c: First immunoglobulin, then Hep B vaccine after 1 month

questions.question: Q4. Which is not a contraindication for OPV?

Q1. Which of the following statements is true regarding the blood carried by the
umbilical vein in fetal circulation, and how many umbilical veins are present?

options.a: The umbilical vein carries deoxygenated blood and there are two umbilical veins.
options.b: The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood and there are two umbilical veins.
options.c: The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood and there is one umbilical vein.
options.d: The umbilical vein carries deoxygenated blood and there is one umbilical vein.

questions.question:
Q2. Which of the following statements regarding fetal circulation is/are true? The left
and right heart in fetal circulation function as a parallel circuit as compared to series
in adults. The placenta is not an efficient oxygen exchange organ as compared to
lungs. Fetal superior vena cava (SVC) blood preferentially flows across the tricuspid
valve, rather than the foramen ovale, into the right ventricle. Because the pulmonary
arterial circulation is vasoconstricted, only approximately 5% of right ventricular
(RV) outflow enters the lungs.
Q3. Which of the following changes does not occur in fetal circulation following birth?

options.b: Increase in mass and volume of the left ventricle
options.d: Increase in mass and volume of the right ventricle

questions.question:
Q4. A 5-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic after a heart murmur was
detected during a recent febrile illness. On examination, the child has a soft ejection
systolic murmur, best heard at the left upper sternal border. The second heart sound
(S2) is normal. The child is asymptomatic, with no history of cyanosis, syncope, or
respiratory distress. The fever has resolved, and the child is otherwise well. What is
the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

options.a: Reassure the parents that the murmur is likely innocent, and no further follow-up is necessary.
options.b: Immediately order an ECG and echocardiogram to rule out congenital heart disease.
options.c: Reassure the parents and schedule a follow-up assessment in a few weeks to reassess the murmur.
options.d: Refer to a pediatric cardiologist for further evaluation without additional tests.

questions.question:
Q5. Which of the following congenital heart defects can exhibit ductus-dependent
pulmonary circulation, where the ductus arteriosus is critical for maintaining
pulmonary blood flow?

Q6. In a large ventricular septal defect (VSD), which factor primarily determines the
direction and magnitude of the left-to-right shunt?

options.b: Ratio of pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) to systemic vascular resistance (SVR)
options.c: Ratio of left ventricular pressure to right ventricular pressure
options.d: Ratio of systemic vascular resistance (SVR) to pulmonary arterial pressure

questions.question:
Q7. A 7-year-old child presents with difficulty in physical activity and a heart
murmur. On examination, the child has a widely split and fixed second heart sound
(S2), a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border, and a mid-diastolic
murmur at the lower left sternal border. The echocardiogram reveals an atrial septal
defect (ASD) located in the fossa ovalis. What is the most likely pathophysiological
consequence of this ASD?

options.a: Decreased right atrial volume due to left-to-right shunting
options.b: Increased pulmonary vascular resistance leading to cyanosis
options.c: Left ventricular overload resulting in heart failure
options.d: Right ventricular volume overload leading to right atrial and ventricular enlargement

questions.question:
Q8. Determine which syndrome linked to atrial septal defect is accurately paired with
its corresponding gene.

options.c: Familial ASD without heart block- NKX2.5

questions.question:
Q9. A 12-year-old child is evaluated for a heart murmur and an ECG is performed.
The ECG shows right axis deviation and minor right ventricular conduction delay.
Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding these ECG findings in the
context of atrial septal defect (ASD)?

options.a: Evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy associated with pulmonary hypertension

questions.question:
Q10. During the physical examination of an infant with a large Patent Ductus
Arteriosus (PDA), which of the following statements is true regarding the findings?

options.a: Continuous machinery-like murmur, radiating to the second intercostal space.
options.b: High-pitched mitral mid-diastolic murmur at apex
options.c: Prominent thrill radiating to right clavicle

severity of the cyanotic spells?

options.a: Size of the ventricular septal defect (VSD)

options.a: Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2)

Q1. In newborns, phytomenadione is routinely administered to prevent hemorrhagic
disease. However, its administration is contraindicated in the presence of a deficiency
in which specific condition?
Q2. Which of the following statements regarding Burkitt’s lymphoma is incorrect?

options.a: It is commonly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, especially in endemic cases
options.b: The disease predominantly affects children and young adults
options.c: The standard treatment typically involves low-intensity chemotherapy due to its slow-growing nature
options.d: The tumor cells typically show translocation t(8;14) involving the MYC gene

questions.question:
Q3. A 17-year-old male is diagnosed with classical Hodgkin’s lymphoma, and staging
investigations reveal stage IIA disease, with involvement of lymph nodes only above
the diaphragm but no B symptoms. Which of the following treatment regimens is
considered the standard approach for initial therapy in this stage of the disease?

options.d: Chemotherapy with vinblastine, etoposide and prednisolone

questions.question:
Q4. Based on the Ann Arbor staging system, which stage is described by the following
features: involvement of two or more lymph node regions on the same side of the
diaphragm, without extranodal involvement?

Q5. A 17-year-old patient undergoing treatment for acute promyelocytic leukemia
develops severe adverse reactions, including high fever, difficulty breathing, and
peripheral edema. What is the most appropriate treatment to manage this patient?

Q6. In a patient with more than 20% blast cells observed in a smear, which of the
following chromosomal abnormalities is NOT useful in differentiating Acute Myeloid
Leukemia (AML) from Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)?

Q7. Which variant of leukemia is most commonly associated with the development of
granulocytic sarcoma?

Q8. A 2.5-year-old child has been diagnosed with severe Acute Lymphoblastic
Leukemia (ALL). Given the high risk of central nervous system (CNS) involvement
with this condition, the oncologist is planning appropriate prophylactic measures.
What is the most appropriate step for prophylaxis to prevent central nervous system
(CNS) involvement in this child?

Q9. A 7-year-old child with Down syndrome presents with symptoms of fatigue,
pallor, and easy bruising. Laboratory tests reveal anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and an
elevated white blood cell count. A bone marrow biopsy shows the presence of
lymphoblasts. Cytogenetic analysis confirms the presence of chromosomal
abnormalities. Which type of leukaemia is most commonly associated with paediatric
patients who have Down syndrome?

Q10. A 5-year-old child is diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL). The
initial diagnostic workup includes a white blood cell count of 15,000/µL, and
cytogenetic analysis reveals hyperdiploidy. The child begins treatment with a standard
chemotherapy regimen and responds well. Which of the following factors is most
indicative of a favourable prognosis for this child?

options.a: The child’s age at diagnosis >1 and < 10 years of age
options.b: The elevated initial white blood cell count ( >50000/µL )
options.c: The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome - t(9;22)

questions.question:
Q11. Which of the following genetic syndromes is not associated with the development
of leukemia in a pediatric patient?

caused by a deficiency in clotting factor VIII. b. It is inherited in an autosomal
dominant pattern. c. It shows increased aPTT and normal PT. d. Patients with severe
Hemophilia A often experience spontaneous bleeding into joints and muscles. Select
the correct answer from the codes given below.

Q13. A 3-month-old infant is being evaluated for anemia. The pediatrician orders a
hemoglobin electrophoresis test, and the results reveal that the majority of the
hemoglobin present is fetal hemoglobin (HbF). What is the predominant hemoglobin
chain composition of fetal hemoglobin found in this infant?

recent platelet count is 32,000/µL, and the child does not exhibit any signs of active
bleeding. What is the appropriate next step in management for this child?

the body, even after 1 month. The pediatrician suspects an underlying coagulation
disorder. Which of the following tests would be most appropriate to assess the
suspected deficiency in this newborn?

Syndrome b Defect in GPIb-IX-V 3 Von Willebrand Disease c Defect in (vWF) 4
Haemophilia A d Defect in Factor 8

Q17. A 15-year-old male presents with a history of chronic fatigue, frequent
nosebleeds, and recurrent infections over the past few months. His laboratory results
show pancytopenia and peripheral blood smear reveals markedly reduced cellularity
without evidence of blasts or dysplasia. A bone marrow biopsy demonstrates severe
hypocellularity with less than 10% hematopoietic cells and prominent fatty
infiltration. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely
diagnosis?

and multiple congenital abnormalities. The child also has distinct skin lesions as

following is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition?

abdominal pain. His medical history includes multiple hospitalizations for anemia
requiring transfusions. Physical examination reveals jaundice and a palpable liver,
but no spleen is felt. Laboratory tests show a hemoglobin level of 7 g/dL, elevated
reticulocyte count, and indirect hyperbilirubinemia. What is the most likely
underlying condition?

a history of repeated blood transfusions. A skull radiograph revealed the following

options.d: Dietary modification to include folate-rich food

questions.question:

started oral iron supplementation. The pediatrician advises the parents that certain
changes and observations can be expected during the initial days of treatment. On the

and pallor. The pediatrician conducts a complete blood count (CBC) to evaluate the

bleeding. The parents also reported a history of bleeding from the umbilicus since

options.c: A single dose of intravenous immunoglobulin

report that he swallowed a small object while playing 2 hours ago. A chest X-ray

questions.question:

distension, and failure to thrive. Initial X-rays reveal dilated bowel loops.

meconium, and bilious vomiting. Physical examination reveals an empty rectum. A
barium enema shows a narrow distal segment with proximal dilation. Which of the

options.d: Excessive production of acetylcholine in the enteric nervous system

questions.question:

unusually irritable and has had abdominal pain and vomiting over the past 24 hours.
On examination, the sausage-shaped mass was palpable over the abdomen. The
barium enema radiograph revealed a coiled spring appearance. What is the most
likely diagnosis?

symptoms occurred after she ate bread or pasta. Tests showed elevated anti-tTG IgA

step of diagnosis?

irritability, and occasional vomiting. The duodenal biopsy is illustrated in the image
below. Which of the following does not accurately describe this condition?

options.d: Treatment includes a high-fiber wheat diet.

questions.question:
Q10. An infant with a 2-week history of loose stools now exhibits noisy, loose stools,
abdominal bloating, and crying, especially after feeding milk. The stool pH is
approximately 6. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Q11. A 4-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to frequent postprandial
regurgitation. The parents report that the infant appears irritable during and after
feeding, frequently arches her back, and has episodes of choking and gagging. On
examination, the infant is mildly irritable with no signs of respiratory distress. What is
the next best step in management?

pneumonia. He is hemodynamically stable but requires IV fluids for maintenance

Q13. A 3-year-old girl presents with severe diarrhoea, sunken eyes, and lethargy.

Q14. A 2-year-old boy presents with a 1-day history of watery diarrhoea and 4
episodes of loose stools in the last 24 hours, but no vomiting. He is alert, drinking
normally, and shows no signs of dehydration. What is the most appropriate initial
management?

options.a: Start ORS and withhold solid foods for 24 hours
options.b: Prescribe an antibiotic and advise clear fluids only
options.c: Continue normal diet with adequate fluid intake and ORS
options.d: Administer ondansetron and start a probiotic supplement

questions.question:
Q15. A 4-week-old male infant presents with projectile vomiting for the past week.
The parents report reduced wet diapers, thirst, and irritability. Examination reveals a
slightly sunken fontanelle, dry mucous membranes, normal heart rate, prolonged
capillary refill of 3 seconds, and slow skin recoil but of <2 seconds. What is the most
likely assessment of this infant's hydration status?

Q16. A 4-week-old male infant presents with projectile vomiting after feeds for two
weeks. On examination, a palpable "olive-like" mass is noted in the epigastric region.
Ultrasound shows a pyloric muscle thickness of 4 mm and a pyloric channel length of
18 mm. The infant is dehydrated but stable. What is the most appropriate next step in
management?

Q17. A 2-week-old infant is admitted with projectile, non-bilious vomiting, visible
gastric peristaltic waves, and a palpable olive-shaped mass. An ultrasound confirms
congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). Which of the following is not a
known risk factor for CHPS?

Q18. A 3-week-old male infant presents with projectile, non-bilious vomiting after
feeds and visible peristalsis in the upper abdomen. On examination, a palpable mass is
noted in the epigastric region. An abdominal ultrasound is performed. Which of the
following radiologic findings would most likely be seen in this condition?

options.a: Elongated pyloric channel on contrast studies
options.b: Pyloric muscle thickness is normal on USG
options.c: Pyloric length of 8 mm on USG

questions.question:
